It's really not often that I give an anime a 10/10 rating, but I feel like Yuri!!! On Ice deserves it for everything it's done. This show gave me the sweet representation that I'd been craving ever since I found my love for figure skating (just kidding- I'm gay, though the figure skating is also cool.) Also, I would go into the whole queerbaiting debate but, at this point, those who still deny sweet Victuuri (get it??) are really stretching to the point where they could literally get married and people would say it was a 'friendship pact' or a 'promise between a coach andstudent'.


(I'll be trying a new review style this time where I simply talk about the five most standout characteristics of the show, whether good or bad, so I hope you enjoy this!)


1 - The characters


Can we just take a moment to appreciate the diversity in this show? We have a Thai skater skating to a piece of music from a movie that showed him representation, a hispanic skater to represent the USA (instead of the stereotypical white guy), and a skater from Kazakhstan! Tell me, when was the last time you watched an anime with a character from Kazakhstan?


And the best part about these characters?


They're all fleshed out. Most of the skaters (excluding the main three) only get two episodes to shine (while the finalists get four, it's still not much). But, it doesn't matter. I found myself learning about and supporting them anyway because, during their short screen time, they got more development than some characters do throughout their entire anime. Props to Kubo-sensei for managing it because writing strong minor characters can be pretty tough (I should know, I'm an author.)


2 - The story


Oh boy. I've seen people complaining that we don't know anything about Viktor's backstory but, honestly? After episode ten I stopped caring: we know him well enough already. Yuri!!! On Ice (or yoi, as I will abbreviate to from now on) is one of the best uses of the unreliable narrator I've EVER SEEN. The show manages to take any confusions and preconceptions about the characters and smash them into little pieces with one, minute long sequence during the credits. A plot twist so good, I had to go back and rewatch the entire show with my new understanding.This is what good writing looks like, take notes, YA authors.


3 - The music


I'm not talking about the voice acting or the backing tracks here, no (those weren't stand-out, personally), I'm talking about the music the skaters skate to. At the beginning of the series, Viktor skates to 'Stammi Vicino', a song pleading a lover to never leave, while not having a lover to speak of- representing his unfulfillment. The track Yuri on Ice, represents Yuuri's entire journey as, not just a figure skater, but a person. The changes in the instruments and tune of the song can actually be aligned to events that happen LATER in the show. It's really quite clever. In yoi, music has about seven layers of meaning- and that's just the title of the piece.


4 - The hype


This show is insanely hyped, I know, but there's good reason. I haven't ever contributed to an anime forum before unless if it was a subject I cared strongly about- with this show, I contributed just because. I felt like I was part of the community build around it- heck, I was one of the ones building the community. As someone who has a hard time enjoying things with even small problems (and not critically taking them apart) for this show, I managed to simply watch it for what it was. And I loved it. I loved it so much that when Wednesday comes and there's no new episode I might cry.


5 - "Viktuuri" (a.k.a. look, mama, spoilers!!)


Hey, here's a radical idea, yoi is not 'shounen ai'or 'yaoi' just because it features a loving and respectful relationship between two male characters. Oh, wait, that's right; yaoi relationships are never respectful (or, heck, even loving.) This might be a bit of an unconventional comparison but let's think about Iron Man 3. It features a relationship between main characters through which they change and better themselves while also finding motivation in other aspects of their life. 


Now let's take a look at yoi: It features a relationship between main characters through which they change and better themselves while also finding motivation in other aspects of their life. 


Wait, did I just type out the exact same summary? Yes, because the two relationships have the exact same effects on the characters and plot. And do we consider Iron Man 3 a romance? Hell no! (I'm also trying to remember if they kiss at all and I don't think they do so I guess we'll just say 'not canon' right? Because that's how it works, right??)


The Summary 


 You don't have to like this show. You don't have to ship the main characters. You just have to respect that the people who do, feel that way, not because they are massive fujoshi watching another yaoi show, but because they connect with the characters and enjoy the plot and subject matter. 


(Because I can already tell that you're wondering: 'why didn't she mention the animation?' The reason, my pals, is that less than half of the skating sequences even come close to living up to the 'Stammi Vicino' sequence in the opening episode. Yes, I'm disappointed. No, I'm not surprised. That high standard was always going to be hard to maintain. It's not bad, though, just not noteworthy.)

[Long Review] Yuri!!! on Ice - Why You Shouldn't Judge It Like A Common Sports Anime
Let's admit that 2016 isn't the best year for anime and Fall 2016 isn't the best season of the year. And then, out of left field, came Yuri!!! On Ice.
"The project was finally green-lit around the time of the Sochi Olympics (2014), when public interest in figure skating was running high." - Kubo sensei's interview with PASH! PLUS in October 2016
Yuri!!! On Ice (YOI) is an original sports anime (with no original manga/novel to base on) dedicated to figure skating and of course, the relationship between Victor and Yuuri. Assomeone who had a little bit of knowledge about figure skating before YOI, I had my fair share of apprehension and skepticism before watching. However, if you're looking for rants about how YOI is "over-hyped" and "unrealistic" and "disastrous", this is not the place. I am unabashedly full of praise for this anime series - which took two years to make - that has rekindled the joy of anime watching in me. With a solid story line and fulfilling characters, YOI truly deserves to be called one of the bests of 2016.


*MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD*


First of all, we need to recognize some differences competitive figure skating has as a sport as compared to most sports anime (e.g. Yowamushi Pedal, KnB, Haikyuu etc)


1) It is an individual sport.


Competitive figure skating, to be specific, Men Singles, is a single man sport that only one best skater can take the title of the World's No. 1. This means that there will be no "team bonding", "team play" and "team fun" that producers always laid on thickly to establish characters and progress plots. Men figure skating is all about competitions after competitions, consecutive practice sessions and adjustments/improvements to programs that are repeated throughout an entire competitive season (lasting a year). It is a very lonely sport on the ice where you constantly pit yourself against yourself, as well as you against your competitors.


2) Skills, confidence and the friendship between competitors. 


Quoting J.J in the final episode, "Given the current totals, I might just be able to claw my way onto the podium if the others mess up, but still...me? Win out of sheer luck? That's not like me at all!"


Interestingly, competitors often share very close relationships with each other in real life (just look at the quad battles and ice shows and banquet dance battles XD), since most likely you'll see the same handful of athletes again and again competitions after competitions (chuckles). Competitive figure skating is of course about gunning for the gold, but they also turn to each other for guidance because ultimately, its more about perfecting your OWN program, about how to land another quad cleanly in competition, and less of tearing down the immediate "enemy" right in front of you. This is very aptly reflected in YOI through the relationship between Yuuri K. and Yuri P, where Yuuri asked for Yuri's help in his quad and Yuri complied, though he may lose the competition if Yuuri did land the quad. Same goes for Minami cheering for his skating buddies (despite competing in the same competition), where similar camaraderie is reflected in multiple friendships, as between Victor and Chris, Yuri and Mila, Leo and Guang Hong, and of course Yuuri and Phichit. More often than not, competitors are often rink mates (think Yuzu and Javi) whom they have stuck through tough times and straightened out heartbreaks together. They may be skating on the ice alone, but lasting friendships are definitely forged on and off the ice. 


3) The explanation of technicalities (or the lack thereof) and the role of coaches


From Wikipedia, "The Salchow is normally approached from a forward outside 3-turn on the left foot for a counterclockwise jump. On the left back inside edge after the 3-turn, the skater checks the rotation momentarily with the right foot extended behind and then initiates the jump by swinging the right leg forward and around with a wide, scooping motion. The rotational momentum for the jump is gained by the swinging movement of the free leg and the coordination of the free leg and arms at the point of takeoff."


Understand the above paragraph? Not really? Adding on with the knowledge that skating blades has two blades commonly referred to as the inner and outer edge? Still no? My point exactly.


One of the main complaints I hear from most people saying that YOI has failed as a sports anime is that they did not explain technicalities, like what axels, loops, lutzs, salchows and flips are. The thing to keep in mind is that YOI is not your common sports anime - these are adult men competing on a professional level for the top spot in figure skating, this is a career, not a beginners after school sports club where you'll have introductory lessons on how to skate circles on the ice. Click on any figure skating commentary on youtube - be it Eurosport, CBC, NBC, Universal HD or individual skating analysts - and that's exactly what they'll say. When they see a biellmann spin, they'll comment "Biellmann Spin", if its a quad toe, they say "Quad Toe" and maybe add on a little about the entrances and exits and whether if the rotations were enough or short. Besides, YOI did touch on important technicalities that we do need to know about, such as the GPF and the point system, although they came across as info dumps in earlier episodes just so to get them out of the way and focus on later competitions. 


Overall I don't think that whether or not you know how an axel is landed affects the story very much, as the programs often speaks for itself. Surely most can recognize  at least an Ina Bauer by now : D


With that out of my chest, lets start with the proper anime review : )



*MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD* 


Story - 10 / 10


YOI starts off with Japanese figure skater Katsuki Yuuri, who at the start of the season, busted his chances at the podium with an error-filled Free Skate and is seriously contemplating about retiring. Defeated, he retreats to his hometown Hasetsu, where his underpopulated but extremely supportive townspeople welcome him home to onsens (hot springs) and katsudons (pork cutlet bowls). There, he skates to his five peat champion/idol's program "Stay Close to Me". To his utmost surprise (and horror), this leads to a viral video and the said idol, Victor Nikiforov, to his doorstep and announcing that he'll be his coach for the upcoming competitive season.From there, they meet with different competitive skaters from different backgrounds, who compete for different reasons, but all for the same goal - the ultimate top spot in the world of competitive figure skating. 


1) "Who told?!" - The Impressive Homework Done 


You know that good work has been done when not one, not two, but a staggering seven real life figure skaters expressed their love and appreciation for the show, and that's only those who've made it known publicly. Evgenia Medvedeva (huge Victuuri shipper XD ), two-time Grand Prix Final champion, received official art from Kubo sensei and figures of YOI after her recent skate in Russia Nationals; Johnny Weir (salutations to the blue rose crown, the feathered costume and the slight reference to his ex-husband Victor Voronov), filled his twitter with YOI updates; Kazakhstani figure skater Denis Ten, who often exchanged YOI tweets with Evgenia, coincidentally rides a black bike;  not to mention Nobunari Oda and Stéphane Lambiel, whose voices made cameos in YOI episodes 10, 11 and 12. Even Evgeni Plushenko, whose achievements so impressive that could drop anyone's jaw once they skimm throgh the first paragraph of his wiki, posted a Japanese tweet on his Facebook page directing readers to Yuri!!! on Ice's Crunchyroll page.


"There have been many strange moments watching a fictionalized version of our world, so much so that I’ve had times when I say to myself, “Who told!?”  There are so many secrets in in the show that only skaters or people very close to them, would know about. Sometimes a character will remind me of a dirty little secret that even hardcore skating fans don’t know about, and while it may not be completely played out in the show, the pink elephant has entered the room." - Johnny Weir interview in December 2016


It is obvious that the creators had really done their homework over the past two years which all in all culminates into this 12 episode anime ultimately names as Yuri!!! On Ice. It took a very simple story line, painstakingly and lovingly, gave it bones, flesh and skin, and finally a breath of life, and sent it to the October screens as an anime to make history.



2) Victor and Yuuri - Friends or Lovers?


YOI Fandom Before Episode 10:

"Something round and golden."

IS IT A RING? Or is it a medal? I mean, I really hope that its a ring, but I guess, I guess, its probably, ehnn, probably a medal... 


YOI Fandom After Episode 10:

WHY DID I BELIEVE IN THE MEDAL INSTEAD OF LOVE



From start till end, YOI challenges our norms and things we take for granted, where they put forth questions that we would never have thought twice about:


- Why should there be a yaoi tag when we don't demand the same from anime depicting hetero relationships?

- Why are people so hung up about a clear indication of "relationship status confirmation" between two men when the couple has already 1)been staying together for about a year, 2)confessed in front of national TV, 3)hugged and cuddled all the time, 4)kissed (as confirmed by the official team), 5)proposed, 6)exchanged engagement rings in a country that recognizes gay marriage and 7) pair-skated in an exhibition event of the Grand Prix Finals, and when their sheer closeness and intimacy clearly says it all?


Love need no words when it is in the air.


And about the issue of how real life gay relationships are definitely not this smooth sailing:


“Regardless of how people in the real world feel about this work, inside the world of this show, there will be absolutely no discrimination toward the things one loves. I will absolutely protect this world.” - Kubo sensei on twitter


Bless you, Kubo sensei.


2) Who are you skating for?


All six skaters want the gold medal. But they do not just skate for the medal.


Through their programs, we hear their inner thoughts. For Yuuri, its almost always about Victor. Victor would like that, Victor would do this, Victor this and Victor that. This is actually one of the parts which make YOI very realistic. When the person you've looked up to all life suddenly came over to your home country and offered to coach you, that would be the most possible reaction from anyone. Of course you'd want to impress him, not to mention that he'd become your fiance in the near future. Competitive skating is very consuming and extremely draining, and as a professional athlete, it is already a given that you're going for the gold of course. The difference is the motivation behind your skating, and for whom you are skating for. Yuri P. skates his Free program thinking about his grandfather, so much so that he fumbles when he's not around; Phichit skates for his home country, to be the first Thai skater to make the Grand Prix Finals and hold an ice show in Thailand; Otabek skate to do his home country proud and to realize his dream and ideals by jumping quads, quads and quads. Yuuri skate to Victor and to his own almost-ending skating career. If he didn't want the gold he wouldn't have made that bold statement "I'll prove it with a gold medal!" during the press conference. To draw an inappropriate parallel, I apologize in advance, there are hardly any voices against Michele skating for Sara even though Sara is all he thinks about in all of his skates...



Art & Animation - 9 / 10


I must give credit to the key animators of YOI because the animation in YOI, albeit imperfect, was on point. There is just something about how the human body moves when they skate - the twirls and the jumps and the landings that all happen under 0.7 seconds - that is impossible to replicate in the limited amount of frames a 13 episode anime season has (It is painfully obvious when you compare it side by side with, as per say, Yuzu's 2016 Gala/Exhibition after the Worlds Championships, my favorite of all time). YOI went all the way out to choreograph all music and programs from scratch, and boy did they deliver splendidly. I am not going to deny that there are parts that needs polishing (please, if you're gonna stop in the middle of a less-than-a-second spin/jump/sequence, of course everything will look poorly animated, duh!), but the aesthetics are pleasant to the eye and some scenes are just straight up beautiful. A lot of attention are paid to the background, especially in episode 10 when they go around sightseeing in Barcelona - just straight out of a postcard. Scenes are believable and wonderfully animated, which pulls up the overall for me to give a 9.



Sound - 9 / 10


Sountracks are memorable and meaningful, and this is what a lot of anime are lacking these days. Songs like "Still Alive", "Theme of King J.J" and "History Maker" roll right off my tongue, Phichit's "Shall We Skate" invigorates the soul and "Tales of a Sleeping Prince" never fails to remind me of Georgi's desperate plea for Anya. "Stammi Vicino" and "Serenade for Two" were on my playlist for a while, and of course, "Yuri on Ice", my favorite piece out of all programs. That piece is pure storytelling with music itself.  




Character - 10


Phichit himself deserves a 10/10 XD Full marks for our Captain!<3 


Character development is slow but steady, ever evolving while keeping close check to the story line. It is established that Victor and Yuuri were conversing in English, as Kubo sensei said, since Yuri studied in Detroit for 5 years apparently he's very fluent in English : D Overall, Yuuri and Victor has the best development, although I feel that Victor has grown more than Yuuri as a character. In the case of Yuuri, its more about a discovery than a development of character - he has a heart of glass, but the inner strength within is remarkable. We just had to take a couple of episodes to find it and let it shine. Yuuri is, in my opinion, a very surprising person. He seems like the plain-est person in YOI but turns out to take the most surprising actions all the time.  Victor, on the other hand, matures into a better coach over the season, as well as a better lover. We also gain insights to Yuri P. and feels greatly for his desire to succeed and how hard he presses himself to improve, improve and improve. One may be put off by his attitude, but it is undeniable that his spirit is admirable and is indeed a good kid at heart. 



Enjoyment - 10


It's not just about the anime - its about the fandom, the author-watchers' interaction and everything else. YOI has, by far, the most supportive and friendly fandom I've found myself in. It's been a roller-coaster of emotions. I feel like I've been spoilt by Kubo sensei. Kubo sensei really takes the effort to engage the audience at a very personal level and that is really sweet. She is really the best sensei ever. 


I arrived looking for an anime about figure skating. YOI gave me professionally-made programs and songs, complicated step sequences, extensive training sessions, back-to-back competitions, improvements and adjustments, confidence shattering and self discovery.


I arrived looking for an anime with friendship and love. YOI gave me the best best best friend ever (Phichit), everyone's son ever (Yuri P.), most emotional skater ever (Georgi), for-some-reason-everyone-is fascinated-with-him-although-he-rarely-speaks Seung Gil, cutest skater ever "Jiayou" Guang Hong, and the best song ever J.J and Leo. And of course the OTP that actually became canon, we were born to ship Victuuri :"D


I had simple expectations for YOI.


I left them at the door and YOI blew my mind.



Sidenotes:

The only dampener I've experienced in YOI is that someone apparently changed Yuzu's wiki from Yuzuru Hanyu to Katsuki Yuri, although it was taken down ASAP when it was known. Overall - 10


If you're looking for something different, for some proper romance with focus on the sport itself, do try out Yuri!!! On Ice! It has been a very thrilling ride and I'll definitely miss the squeezes and clawing and breathlessness in my heart when waiting for a new episode every week. Bless you guys who can marathon it in a single sitting now, so jealous but so happy its unexplainable.

Why should you watch Yuri!!! on Ice?  
It's a sports anime for people who generally Don't Get sports anime.  Ice skating is a combination of art, performance, as well as technical ability, it's not a sport based off of teamwork and cooperation. It's like, Extreme Ballet to put it in layman terms.  If you love ballet and dance, then I think you will love the premise. Every character has a theme for their routines and each song is chosen to express how they feel.  The anime will repeat performances but every time a character performs the same routine, how they feelwill affect their overall achievement. There is an artistic beauty to ice skating which I personally find more interesting than the power of friendship securing victory over a rival sports team.


Another reason to watch the show is how refreshingly modern it is. For one thing, even though the MC is Japanese, the rest of the cast is international, and not even in a conventional way. The American ice skater is Mexican American, there's skaters from Thailand, Italy, Korea, Russia, Kazakhastan, China, & even Czech. The obnoxious arrogant ice skater is Canadian. The MC is Japanese, but his coach/love interest is Russian.  Another thing is the brilliant use of technology and social media.  Yes this is a sports anime, but the cast all have smartphones, and they all post photos and status updates to various media websites. The show also pokes fun at social media fan gossip, which is common in the world of competitive ice skating. This is what the 2016 looks like right now, and its lovely to see it represented in the show.


A lot of people are interested in this show because of the gay romance between Yuri (the MC) and Victor (his coach). This is a very subtle romance, and their relationship isn't just romantic, its more complex than that. Victor is Yuuri's coach, and Yuuri is Victor's muse. Their love for each other is tangled in between the two. I'd say that while their eventual romance is very important to the development of the story, its not going to be satisfying if that's the only reason you're watching it.  They are both professional ice skaters, so their relationship, naturally, revolves and grows around that. And because of that, the romance between the two of them is told through the story of ice skating and their performances, not through declarations of love. When push comes to shove, this is a sports story which has romance in it, not the other way around.


Lastly, I want to say that the finale is kind of rushed, and that is why I give this series a 9/10 and not a 10/10. The finale basically throws in a twist to set up for season 2. At the time I am writing this review, the actual date for season 2 hasn't been announced, but please keep this in mind.


Besides the finale, the show is very entertaining and full of love, and it does a wonderful job at displaying all kinds of love, from Yuuri & Victor's romance, to the love of ice skating that binds everyone else together. It's a passion project I haven't seen in a long, long time, and for that reason I think you'll like it too!

This review is spoiler free, so please enjoy.
The sports anime 'Yuuri!!! on Ice' is a new addition to the plethora of sports anime out there. At the time of airing it's extremely popular with both those in the anime community and 'beginners' in anime. Here's my take on it.
Story: 7/10
In my eyes, most sports anime story lines come off as generic, to say the least. And I'm saying that as a person who really likes the genre. With YOI, however, I saw something a little bit different, though it follows the same basic outline as other sports shows. In short, it's Yuuri's journey to tryand win some sort of national ice skating competition coached by Victor who Yuuri has been a complete fanboy of for ages. I like how it's very relevant and most of the people who watch it can relate to Yuuri. Not only is the show funny and at some times quite bizarre it can be very serious at times. The pacing of the show is not bad, though I think I'd like to see more of Yuuri's practice sessions. The story's pretty solid overall, though it's the other elements of the show that make it really shine.



Art: 8/10


I really enjoyed the art in the show, for the most part. Firstly, the opening theme art was beautiful. It was cinematic, subtle and fit the mood of the whole show which I thought was done very well. Art in the show was above average for sure - there was detail in all the right places and I didn't have any problems with  it. The only real art problem, as I'm sure many are aware, was the actual skating animation(ironic, it being a skating anime)which had some under done parts. The skating tended to be quite choppy which could have been fixed possibly with a bigger budget. However, it's bearable, so don't let that put you off the whole show.


Sound: 9/10


The sound in the show is on the whole great. It always fits the moment and is well chosen for the genre it's based on. It's very uplifting and compliments any scene it's put in. The theme music for each skater fitted their personalities. I didn't like some of the skating tracks, but that's overshadowed by the sheer brilliance of the other ones. 


Character: 8/10


Though some of the characters were quite unforgettable, some really shone. There's quite a cast since there's lots of people skating and it seemed like the show wanted you to remember everyone, which of course was impossible. However, they delivered well on lots of aspects in characters, mainly the main characters Yuuri and Victor. Of course, extremely memorable characters, well designed, likeable personalities, etc. What I found quite interesting was the LGBT route tackled in the show. I'm extremely glad that the show does not lose touch of the fact that it is a sports anime. It'd be very easy to leave all the ice skating behind and turn this whole show into a giant yaoi fest, but gladly it does not(though I do enjoy a bit of yaoi now and again). It's very interesting and is one of the reasons I actually picked up the show, though I won't say too much so you can enjoy it yourself. But yes, lots of diversity and memorable people there for you to enjoy whose characters are quite well developed.


Enjoyment: 9/10


Oh, how I loved Wednesdays. I'd sit in my chair, counting down till Crunchyroll posted that fateful episode. Though the show had little flaws, and wasn't my favourite show in the universe, it was certainly exciting, keeping me entertained every week and giving me lots to talk about with those who had seen it. I really did enjoy it.


Overall: 8/10


I could overlook the flaws in this show just because it was great. It showcased well the comedy, drama and romance that comes with ice skating competitively and infatuated me in something that I may have not been interested in before. Well done, Yuuri!!! on Ice.

It's strikingly obvious how the reviewers giving this more than 8 are all fangirls into yaoi.
Yuri on Ice(or rather Yaoi on Fire) isn't crap by any standards, but seriously, the flood of 9s and 10s for a show that just isn't impressive past the first one or two episodes is unsettling.
In short:
Story: 4 :
A gay romance between an ice skating coach and his trainee. Lots of skating competitions and the romance gets deeper in a super straightforward way.
Art: 5 : I find the animation to be sorely lacking in ice skating scenes, which to their credit is very very hard to do dynamically
Sound: 5 :No comment on the music since it's always in the background of the commentary, but from what I could hear it doesn't fly high

Character: 9 : A very solid and interesting lead, a fantasy man, some rivals in love and a whole lot of other pointless characters. But the lead drew me in by himself so deeply that I felt like finishing the entire anime, so high mark.

Enjoyment: 7 : The competitions tend to drag due to poor animation and uninteresting rivals, and the rest is mostly nice. It's mainly Yuri though, I want to see his story end.

Overall: 7 : A very well done schlock romance at the start that devolves into a well done schlock romance after the first two-three episodes. I certainly enjoyed watching it but it's by no means amazing.


In long, let's just compile a short list of qualities:


-It's a novel subject, I never paid attention to ice skating before this

-It's got a very well developped protagonist in the first episodes

-It's generally well made and has characters and tropes you just don't see often in anime


Past these few, I don't think YOI offers much or anything else.


I expected a lot of gay entering this and it was way worse than I thought. And when I say worse, I mean two men putting twin rings on their 4th fingers in a church worse. No it's not a manner of speaking. It happens.


Did the gay bother me? Not beyond anything more than a laugh, honestly. Despite this being obviously written by a gay male, or at the very least a female very much into yaoi, it never got overbearing to a breaking point. I shielded my eyes from some "crying on shoulder" scenes and some kiss/loving hugs a few times, but it really never bothered me, else I'd just have quit.


What bothers me with YOI is that there is very little PAST the gay romance.


It all started quite well frankly, with a novel protagonist that was pretty well written and lots of elements that felt new or just well made. It was another lonely hero that's on the lowest part of the ladder, with everyone despising him or ignoring him, but he wasn't acting like a Naruto about it. He was crying in the bathroom like a bitch. He also was 23, and had most of his skating career behind him. And it wasn't a pretty sight.


I liked that. I liked the idea of showing a completely earnest protagonist who also happened to be in a bad spot, lacking confidence, not being a brat or some over-optimistic kid. It was just a dude down on his luck crying because he got kicked in the face by life and his own mistakes. It got me interested.


Along with the interesting spin on main characters, the writing was quite solid and I felt that YOI was going to take me for my favorite kind of ride, the kind where I slowly like the people I'm watching more and more till I just can't help but become a complete fanboy and scream internally that I want them to win.


And that feeling went away quite quickly.


YOI just cannot keep its plot and characters interesting past the gay romance. And in case you think the romance is enough, well, I'll have to say that no. Yuri himself is well portrayed yes, but I didn't find Victor to be anything else than a half-schlocky crap romance novel hero, the kind who's just here to be the author's wonderboy. He's not awful or anything, but if Yuri's interesting as a person, Victor is only there as a fantasy.


Worse than that, past the first two episodes where Yuri's personality is well built and deepened, there are no new characters that really come in to pile on and build a powerful cast. You just have Yuri, who's sort of done by then and doesn't give much more till the end of the anime, Victor is just a fantasy, the other Yuri is just a rival, and none of the side characters are all that fantastic.


It's just a typical fangirl yaoi romance. I'll even be a little mean and say that it was probably written by one of these high-selling romance authors who just write 50 shades of grey-tier schlock.


As for the ice skating, I seriously think that the animation just doesn't click. In the first episodes I was stunned that while I was shown something that was supposed to be beautiful, it was clear that technically, it was lacking. Yuri often ended up too deep in the background after a jump, making it look like he jumped 5 meters away from the camera. It took me out of the majesty of ice skating reaaaaaaally fast. It got better with later episodes, but to be blunt, I think you'd need a crazy amount of technical talent and effort to portray it perfectly. I just didn't feel for what I was watching because of all the animation impurities.


But instead of just complaining, here's my take on how to fix YOI:

-Make victor a lot less shit. He's such a blatant fantasy man that I can't even care about his story with Yuri, at all. Make him more human, and more than that develop how he became so talented and what his story was. You can't show me Yuri and Russian Yuri and all the others suffering through months of effort and then show me Victor doing it all seemingly effortlessly and expect me to buy this guy.


-Deepen the other characters and give them stories too. Apart from the annoying Canadian at the end, I don't think anyone in this show has an actual story and goals apart from winning the Final. Time spent on the Italian siscon guy is wasted IMO, since I don't know him, her, and don't care about them. Either develop them properly, either don't waste time on them at all. They build-ish something with Russian Yuri, but it comes around episode 9 and he's stuck in the rut of the "rival in love" for far too long.


-If they wanna focus equally on romance and ice skating, fine. But then do it like Horimiya, which had the intelligence of building the two leads, then very slowly building two, three more couples along. It's a great mix to put competition and love together, but if all they have is one couple, then the competition rivals just end up being jobbers. And nobody cares about a competition of one or two guys and ten jobbers.

As anyone who follows anime on a seasonal basis will know, Yuri!!! on Ice (often shortened to YOI, as I will in this review) quickly became a huge hit and sensation, with some even claiming it was going to be the Anime of the Year. Admittedly, it wasn't one of the series I initially picked up when the Fall 2016 season began since I already had a sports anime in my queue (Haikyuu!! S3), but when I dropped one series that failed to pique my interest and caught up with everything else I was watching, I decided to give YOI a shot to see whatall the hype was about.


Not gonna lie, I was hooked after watching the first couple of episodes.


Yuri!!! on Ice is the story of 23-year-old Yuri Katsuki, a professional skater who has failed to win competitions over and over again and is on the verge of retiring. Then, in drops Viktor Nikiforov, the current star and living legend in men's figure skating, as well as Yuri's idol. Viktor, having his attention caught by a video of Yuri copying one of his programs flawlessly, offers to coach Yuri in his last season of professional skating, promising to get him gold in the Grand Prix Final.


While the story seems pretty cut and dry, it's actually a rather fresh take at the sports genre. Most sports-focused anime start with the underdog, someone new to the sport, showing their struggle to the top. In contrast, Yuri is actually considered Japan's best male figure skater and one of the best in the world overall. He has the talent and the work ethic, but his critical weakness is his lack of confidence. Added to that, at the age of 23 going on 24, he isn't as young and spry as many of the other top competitors he must face, and as a result, is facing the prospect of retiring without having achieved anything of note in his career. To any young adult, this is a huge weight. So, while Yuri is still something of an underdog, we as the audience know better - he's a world class athlete in his sport, so he skates with other athletes in the same level of competition.


As a result, the maturity of the characters shown in this series is a breath of fresh air. Of course, younger characters like Yuri Plisetsky act like a bratty kid and some of the older characters will act goofy for comedic effect, but for the most part, the characters act their ages. They are competing on national and world stages, spend hours upon hours practicing and training, and must have the mental strength to deal with the immense pressure that comes with high-level competitions. When they lose, they are disappointed and crushed, as expected, but are still gracious enough to thank their supporters and wish their fellow competitors luck.


Speaking of maturity, let's move on to the elephant in the room: the same-sex relationship between Viktor and Yuri. One of the more interesting aspects of this anime is how normal their relationship feels. No one makes a huge deal out of the fact that they're two men who love each other. Their families and friends are supportive. And best of all, Viktor and Yuri have a healthy relationship. Sure, there's the occasional misunderstanding or points where they have their doubts, but in terms of relationship drama, it's far less than most other romance anime out there. When one says something that unintentionally hurts the other, they talk about it, learn more about each other, and move on. Again, it's just a nice breath of fresh air.


Where the anime falls short is all the other characters besides Yuri and Viktor. YOI is unfortunately only a one-cour series, even though it would have done much better as a two-cour. YOI boasts a huge supporting cast, mostly due to the sheer number of other competitors that Yuri skates against. This is inevitable given the nature of competitive figure skating. However, the writers tried to squeeze in in-depth characterizations in addition to showing all the skating routines, and then this is multiplied by the three (yes, three) official competitions shown in this 12-episode series. This means that a character is often introduced in one episode, gets a quick explanation of who they are and why they're skating, and then if they don't move on to the next level, we never see them again (at least, not in a meaningful way).


It almost begs the question: what was the point of dedicating so much time to them, then? I would have much rather the writers focus on a select few characters to develop them further than try to develop some twenty but only at a surface level. Character development feels rushed, and the writers often just tell the audience about them rather than show, which just feels contrived and forced. Having YOI be a two-cour anime would have definitely helped in this regard, though, which is a shame. A lot of the supporting cast are genuinely interesting, but a lack of screen time really hurts them in the grand scheme of things (and by extension, hurts the development of the main cast, as well, since the show takes time away from them to develop side characters that barely affect the narrative).


Which brings me to the animation. The first three-ish episodes of YOI were a feast for the eyes with skating routines being shown with exquisite attention to detail and the skaters' movements smooth and flowing, just like a real figure skater's. After that, it becomes painfully clear that MAPPA had reached its limit and could not continue that level of animation for the entirety of the series. Skating routines became clunky and choppy, with more moments of characters looking off-model. As with characterization, I then have to wonder why they didn't just pick and choose more carefully which skating routines to animate? By the time the series was three-quarters over, it was starting to feel tiring to watch a bunch of skating routines back-to-back, especially when the animation wasn't as fluid and the characters barely make any impact on the story or the main characters.


Granted, I have to give credit where credit is due. Animation is time-consuming and difficult. There's a reason why slice-of-life anime series are so common - they require relatively little animation (and thus, time and budget) compared to the intense animation sequences found in action or sports anime. Animating figure skating - and numerous instances of figure skating, at that - was an ambitious project to take on, and considering what they were working with, MAPPA did well overall. A lot of attention to detail was put into knowing their jumps and spins and animating them appropriately. Geographic locations are also spot-on in how they were drawn. The opening credits backgrounds change as the series progresses. Personally, as a Canadian, I got a kick out of seeing the upside-down Canadian Tire logo on J.J.'s jacket (as well as the fact that they pronounce his last name, Leroy, correctly). The studio clearly put a lot of work and passion into this series.


Another feather in MAPPA's cap in this series is the soundtrack. The soundtrack is fantastic, featuring a variety of different genres to reflect each character's preferences and personalities. The OP is an uplifting pop song entitled "History Maker", which is about, well, making history - Yuri's goal to take gold at the Grand Prix before he retires. The ED, "You Only Live Once", is a catchy electro-pop song that had me playing it on repeat for a few days, and perfectly captures the feeling Yuri has about his desire to accomplish something before he retires, as well as enjoying the time he has with Viktor. Scattered between these are the numerous songs the characters dance to - from Yuri's sultry "On Love: Eros" theme to Yurio's soft, angelic "On Love: Agape" to Phichit's bombastic musical number, "Shall We Skate?" You are bound to find at least a couple of likeable tracks.


All in all, YOI is a highly enjoyable anime and popular for a very good reason. I really do wish it had gotten a second cour to further flesh out its huge cast of characters, but considering its subject material and the fact that it's an anime original series, I imagine it would have been difficult for the studio to get funding for two whole cour without proving it could be successful first. In that case, I wish the writers had chosen more carefully what to spend time and animation budget on more wisely. Even despite these flaws, the series still feels compelling and fun, as well as groundbreaking in more ways than one. If you're looking for a feel-good sports anime and don't mind two normal male characters loving each other, then I'd highly recommend Yuri!!! on Ice.

So I have so much to say about this show that, to keep from rambling, I'm going to organize my thoughts into different sections. I'll try not to be too spoilery, for those who haven't seen it because this show needs to be seen.
Story: 
First of all, I came into this show knowing NOTHING about competitive figure skating. But the amount of detail and passion the creator, director, and staff had for the sport was very apparent to the point where I got very interested in learning more about the sport itself while watching the show. That was something that surprised me about the show;how invested it could get me into a sport I'd known nothing about. The story of the competition was well paced and I love that you could never tell how each competitor was going to place. Yuuri Katsuki wasn't guaranteed first or second or third JUST because he was the main character and I liked that the show didn't resort to cliches. 


Regarding the romance in the show, I LOVED how it was handled. I'm usually very picky about romance in anime. I usually check out of it if the romance is TOO sugary-sweet or filled with too much unnecessary drama. Yuri on Ice didn't have that. I got to enjoy a simple romance between two characters who clearly cared about each other and there was little drama about it. I know a lot of people went crazy over the fact that the romance was between two men, but as someone who doesn't care about making a big deal out of orientations (hey, if you love someone, you love someone), I was glad the show didn't make a big deal out of that too. Again, it wasn't super cliched and made me very invested in seeing them happy in the end, which doesn't happen often for me.


Overall, I loved that the story was well-written in both major aspects of the show, I liked how it handled its various themes throughout the show and didn't leave plot threads dangling at the end. I liked that I could go back to the beginning of the show and watch the first few episodes after episode 10 and find that certain lines held a completely different meaning the second time around, because that shows layers in the writing. Anything I can go back and analyse, I appreciate a little more.


Art: After watching Terror in Resonance two years ago and then hearing that MAPPA was doing Yuri on Ice, I was interested in seeing how the art/animation would be for this show. I was not disappointed. I can admit that there were a few sup-par frames from time to time and a few frames were reused, but the show overall looked very beautiful.  The ice skating scenes, especially, were choreographed and animated quite well (good job Kenji Miyamoto and the animation staff at MAPPA) and I loved that the skating scenes were animated slightly differently so you could actually tell if a skater was getting tired or was panicking or feeling down and the performances didn't look stale. But outside of that, I loved how the characters were drawn. What really struck me was how easily you could read expressions on faces. It was always very clear how a character was feeling, even if they weren't speaking and that level of detail impressed me. I also loved that, with each episode, the opening animation had a little bit more color added to it. That was a nice extra touch.


Sound: Now, I love music so, even if I wasn't going to enjoy the show, I knew from the beginning that I would watch it JUST FOR THAT OPENING THEME. It was so inspiring and so powerful that I immediately downloaded (and later bought) it to listen to over and over. The rest of the music in the show was also great. Each piece that each skater had to perform to had its own energy to it and matched each character perfectly, either to them directly or to the theme they were trying to convey, and I never felt like skipping any performance. 


Characters: In sports anime, I think its really easy to fall back on cliched characters so you know who to root for and who to boo at. Yuri on Ice, again, doesn't do that. It speaks volumes to me when the final six skaters go into the Grand Prix Final and I cannot genuinely cannot tell you a single character that I think deserves the gold medal over the others. Each character has their own unique motivations and personalities and flaws that make them endearing. There was only one character I disliked AND EVEN THEN, I could see how other people would like seeing a character like him and, by the end of the show, I came to at least respect him. That speaks volumes to the writing of the show, again.


Enjoyment: Well I'm still riding on the high of the finale, but I'd definitely make this my show of 2016. It was going to be Mob Psycho 100, but I've changed my mind for all the reasons above. I loved watching the skating and getting invested in each performance at every step of the competition. I loved fawning over Yuri and Victor's relationship as it developed in every episode. I laughed at all the character interactions. I cried at the ending. Yeah, I loved this show and I'd definitely recommend it!

Like other sports anime or anime that deal with competitions, there will always be moments where it's too intense, & were the reason why I wouldn't watch it again. But Yuri!!! on Ice was perfect, & I will rewatch this again sometime.
Art- The animators try their best during the ice skating, & we do see the animation develop. It's not the best, but it continues to grow. The animation for the opening and ending is amazing, & there's beautiful scenery.

Enjoyment - SIGN ME UP FOR VICTUURI MMM BOIII \n
Victuuri - c'mon, we can't leave it out. Yuuri & Victor's relationship is just...perfect. Kubo-sensei is a amazing person for creating this natural & realistic relstionship. This isn't meant for fujoshis, nor is it a yaoi anime. It's a ice skating anime with a natural relationship between two guys. Victor & Yuuri's love for each other is just a blessing.\n

As the story progresses, Yuuri learns to be confident in himself as well as his skill while Viktor supports andbelieves in him all the way. 


I totally started shipping Viktor and Yuuri since episode 3 probably and thought this show was like most sports anime where the creators tease the fans with fangirling moments of the two. Character- 10 

The characters in this show are very unique and interesting as well as everyone having their own kind of special personality. No skater in the show had very similar personalities and everyone was different in a good way which got the watchers interested in every new character. I absolutely loved the character development as well as the show being from Yuuri's point of view most of the time. Enjoyment- 10

I totally enjoyed every single second of this show two or three times since I always find myself rewatching each episode and noticing new things every time! I reviewing this anime assuming it is meaning to be emotional and have hints of shounen-ai.
● Story ●
Yuri On Ice has a simple plot line. Yuri, a male figure skater, is down on his luck and returns home. This is where the simple story line turns into it’s own unique adventure. Similar to many modern stories, Yuri goes viral with his routine in which his old friend’s children uploaded to a video site. He meets Viktor after her takes notice of Yuri’s perfected performance.
It’s similar to when people would go viral and get a contract, well that happened here as well.
Viktor ditches his own careerto coach Yuri to Yuri’s surprise. With hard work and effort, he manages to get back on his feet.


Throughout the rest of the story, there are many ups and downs. Yuri goes through very emotional moments when the pressure of the competition begins to weigh on him and it is very humbling.


The story may make one feel nervous of the outcomes of the characters’ performance and leave you on the edge of your seat wishing them the best as they go out to the ice.


I personally got nervous whenever they were making a jump, but when the successfully did I cried out for joy. I was really rooting for them.


● Art ●


The art style is nice. The animation has nice line work and coloring, especially in the scenes of downtime (when they aren’t skating). The skating animation is very awkward, but it is very hard to animate the programs of consecutive 2-3 minutes scenes with animation deadlines of course. I assume they will fix some of the more awkward frames up before the DVD release.


● Sound ●


Yuri On Ice’s soundtrack is very good. The sounds vary from character to characters. Surprisingly, the majority of the sounds are in English. As you would expect in an international competition, all of the characters have different tastes in music and performances. The opening “History Maker” begins the triumphantly and really gets your heart racing for the beginning. The other tracks are rather spam-mable. Personally, I can’t get enough of “Shall We Skate?”, “Still Alive” and “Intoxicated”.


● Characters ●


The characters are different. I could not really define most of them into a single archetype.


The best thing about the characters is that they are not very over powered, and everything doesn’t go they’re way.


The author could have easily made Yuri land all of his jumps and step sequences, and even compete against Viktor to win gold at the Grand Prix Final. The same goes for every other character. The characters who have an even better game plan and land all of their jumps could suddenly be on a losing slope, and dark horses emerge.



● Enjoyment ●


I love Yuri on Ice. It was a lovely adventure to follow all of the characters as they chased their dreams, whether they succeeded or failed. It was also very lovely to follow the relationship(?) of Yuri and Viktor. It gives the anime a lot of shounen-ai vibes. I am personally a fan of the shounen-ai and yaoi genre (as well as yuri), so the scenes with them made my inner fangirl burst out. Even so, I will not let that affect my review.


If you don’t like a bit of shounen-ai, then you might be a bit uncomfortable when it is presented.

And if you don’t like sports anime, then how did you get here?

Six or so episodes into this anime, it felt like I'd finally found it: a sports anime that was more than just queer-bait, something that was well directed with good pacing, and avoided worn tropes of sports anime (something about a start-up high school club that's just trying to make it in the big leagues), and also with well-developed characters. Unfortunately, however, in the end, Yuri on Ice proved itself to be somewhat of a disappointment.
For the first four or five episodes, we get the set up to a somewhat not believable but highly engaging plot. Professional figure skater Yuri Katsuki has just had adisappointing failure at the Grand Prix finals in figure skating do to his inability to handle anxiety under pressure. However, during the off-season, a video leaked of him perfectly skating a routine the legendary Viktor Nikiorov had broken records with the previous season. Viktor comes all the way from Russia to meet Yuri, and in the process upsets his home-country protege, also named Yuri (Plisetsky). Yuri (usually called Yurio in the anime) travels all the way to Japan too and him and our main character Japanese Yuri compete to have Viktor as their coach by skating to sets that oppose their personalities choreographed by Viktor himself. I won't spoil what happens in this, but this was far and away the best part of the series. We had fluidity between the artform of skating and character development, we got to know a relatively few amount of characters but they were thoroughly well developed. 


The only somewhat disappointing part of these first few episodes were what appeared at first to be simple queer-baiting for comedy, however it very quickly turns out to be more than this as several hints (some subtle, some not so much, but I'll avoid spoiling) develop for an actually meaningful relationship between Viktor and Yuri. Fortunately, this never becomes the main focus on the anime and is normalized as a background development rather than used as a gimmick to attract a target audience, which earns it some marks, although at times it got awkward trying to balance this part of Viktor and Yuri's plot with everything else going on at the end (more on that later). Though at the end of the day it got awkwardly shoehorned in, Yuri and Viktor's developing relationship early on was one of the highlights of this anime.


So far, this is sounding like a good review. But along comes episodes six and seven, and now some of Yuri on Ice's flaws come to the forefront. We begin to follow Yuri, Yuri-o, and Viktor through the core of the competitive figure skating season. In these episodes (and throughout the series, but especially here), the beauty of the show's stellar animation comes to life as we see wonderfully directed scenes of all the skaters doing their routines. Unfortunately, this is all we see--with the exception of one episode--for the rest of the series.


At this point, it becomes clear that trying to fit this much into 12 episodes was too ambitious. We meet too many characters too quickly who are all extremely under-developed, their entire backstories are just told with voice-overed thoughts while they skate in competitive matches. Most are not developed at all, and if they try to make them dynamic (such as the favorite to win the gold, a bombastic skater from Canada named JJ begins to get nervous), they do so in a contrived, rushed fashion. The development of our main characters becomes almost a distraction from just trying to fit as many somewhat monotonous, albeit beautifully animated, skating performances that are overly dramatized with characters just spoon-feeding their emotions to the viewer into each episode. 


The few moments that we aren't just watching figure skating performances with over-acted dramatic voice-overs and flashbacks, we're seeing somewhat contrived drama in Yuri and Viktor's relationship where they'll randomly threaten to leave each other for no good reason that are immediately resolved for no good reason. By episode 9, the last three episodes have blurred together as they were all nearly identical; Yuri starts out crying, him and Viktor have a little pep-talk/hugging and crying session, all the skaters do performances where they try to dramatize some portion of their backstory with voice-overs and flashbacks while they're doing their performance, we see the skaters get their scores and react, the episode ends. Episode ten is a welcome break from this formula, but it unfortunately gets full of randomly rushing Yuri and Viktor's relationship at a much faster pace than is at all believable and ill-fated attempts at humor to humanize the other characters who, up until this point, we have no reason to sympathize with at all. Most of them we've only spent five minutes with watching them skate up until this point, and I realize at this point with some amount of disappointment that there are only two episodes, and I'm probably never going to have a chance to give a damn about any of these characters except for Yuri and Viktor, whose entire development has been so sidelined and rushed to cram everyone else in that I'm beginning to not care about them either.


But maybe, I think, this can redeem itself in the next two episodes. And, nope, the last two episodes are virtually indistinguishable from the 6-9, except now it's the final so all the characters can act a little bit more dramatic. By the end, it just kind of feels monotonous and hollow.


In sum we have a well-set up plot with a handful of good characters in the first few episodes marred by obnoxiously faced pacing halfway through the series and sidelined by a bunch of half-baked characters whose entire subplots are spoon-fed in an overused, rushed, formulaic fashion, with only contrived drama and bad humor to break the monotony. But not all is lost, though the skating routines got very repetitious halfway through, they were gorgeously animated with an amazing attention to detail, and certainly those who enjoy figure skating will appreciate the amount of effort that went into depicting their sport. Some of the cinematography and camera angles that went into directing these scenes is gorgeous and innovated, even though they're overused and worn by episode 9. The first few episodes were, if a bit overbearing with the humor, still really good and the way Yurio, Yuri, and Viktor interact in those episodes is some fine character development. Further, the character designs (purely in terms of animation) are top knotch, among the best I've ever seen (if only they had some substance behind the pretty faces). The soundtrack is, also, for the most part really good, with a healthy mixture of emotional original tracks, peppy pop music, and great classical music for the skater's performances, as well as decent background music that matches the era of the transition scenes. But the fact that I'm thinking of anything that isn't a performance, where the characters are actually supposed to interact and develop as a "transition scene" is evidence of how rush and monotonous this anime got at the end.


Still, if you're going to go for a sports anime, at least this tries to step out of the cliched tropes of queer-baiting with bishounen high schoolers. Further, it earns some points for developing a gay relationship that wasn't the somewhat insulting and abusive shounen-ai variety, or just hinting at it to bait the fujoshi (ahem, Free!), and consequently, I'd recommend it over most of the close substitutes in its genre. Perhaps if they had tried to do what this did in 25 episodes it could've been salvaged.

Yuri!!! on Ice is one of the best sports anime in recent years. It managed to have an engaging story with interesting characters, good animation and great music. I came for the cute guys ice skating and stayed for the story and characters.
The concept is nothing new, it's about a sport tournament with behind the scenes drama just like any other sports anime. However, the take on it is what makes it stand out. First of all, it is NOT set in highschool (WHAT A TWIST!) which makes it feel a bit more mature. The main character is a professional trying to restore his damagedcareer, not just a highschool student in a sports club. His struggles as a professional and his relationships with his friends and rivals is what drives the story, rather than just a motivation to "win for the senpais" that would graduate next year (like in almost any other sports anime). Also, since this anime is not about a team sport, the creators had a lot of room to bring out individual characters to drive the story rather than teams of characters. I think choosing figure skating was a smart choice because it's an unpredictable sport. You always have a chance to redeem yourself after an off performance, but an off performance can also kill your winning streak and destroy your season. You can never tell who would win or lose until the very last moment, which added a lot of suspense to each and every performance.

But sports anime are not just about sports! There is also drama, fights and friendship! But in Yuri!!! on Ice there is more than that. In addition to having executed the friendship and rivalry drama much better than most, it was also able to incorporate romance in the story! Usually sports anime avoid that territory since the other elements take up too much of the story and since there are usually not enough female characters, but this didn't stop this anime from creating a romance between two guys (that is not a bromance and did not involve a love triangle, surprisingly). Overall, the story was a very refreshing take on a genre I personally thought was done to death long ago and I love it.


When it comes to characters, this anime did a great job as well. Since figure skating is a single's sport, there was no need to create a lot of one dimensional characters just so there would be enough characters to form several teams. For that reason, careful attention was given to each character and all characters (both main and supporting characters) had depth to them. they all had different motivations, different personalities and not a single character was bland or boring. There were little to no tropes and it felt really nice to watch a sports anime with interesting unique characters (which became quite uncommon recently).


The animation was good, but people have been giving it more credit than is should have got. Yes, the designs were awesome, the character animation during the skating scenes was very good and the direction by Sayo Yamamoto was great. But the animation was also quite inconsistent at times, the characters didn't always fit the background of the scene (the 2D backgrounds looked too much like paintings sometimes, the CGI backgrounds were okay), and they reused a lot of the animations. Also, during the skating scenes (with few exceptions) each frames were given significantly less attention and a lot of the animations that did not involve skating weren't very impressive on their own. the animation was very good, but not outstanding like some people were led to believe.


The soundtrack deserves a 10/10 for sheer diversity alone! The soundtrack has alot of high quality tracks in different genres ranging from classical to boogie to electronic and more. Some of the tracks are homages to famous pieces of music, like "shall we skate" (a musical theater inspired song) referencing "shall we dance" from the king and I (the skater's outfit even resembles that of the king) , or Allegro Appassinato in B minor being heavily inspired by Tchaikovsky's first piano concerto in B flat minor (3rd movement). I think the main reason the series was able to achieve this is because there were two composers working on the soundtrack, and they both did an amazing job. It's honestly the first time I considered to by a soundtrack for an anime once it comes out.

The voice actors also did a pretty decent job portraying their characters.


Now, the series isn't perfect. A lot of characters were pushed aside and were undeveloped and almost forgoten about, there are some problems in the animation and if you're not used to same sex relationships in anime, the interaction between Yuuri and Viktor would feel weird and just make you uncomfortable sometimes. But there's a second season coming (probably), so those things might still be fixed. It is one of the best sports anime I've had the pleasure of watching and I highly reccomend it!

“You have to do the opposite of what people expect. How else will you surprise them? That’s my motto.”  - Victor Nikiforov, Yuri on ICE!!!
If there is one thing this show did well, it was surprise me.  I came into this show expecting to see a cool sports anime about figure skating. I got so much more out of it than that. 
Story: 8/10
This story starts out simply: a Japanese figure skater, Yuri, screws up big time at the most important competition of his life.  He feels like a total loser. And cries in a bathroom stall. Which is something we’ve alldone, just admit it.  He goes home, defeated, and wonders if he should retire from skating.

But everything changes when his idol, the Russian skating genius/handsome bachelor shows announced in his family hot spring, and announces that he is going to take the season off just to coach Yuri. (He makes this shocking announcement butt-ass naked, by the way. Never change, anime.)

From there, the show progresses quickly.  Yuri trains and goes to competition. He slowly gains self- confidence. And the relationship between Yuri and Victor grows.


**MINOR SPOILER***


Yep. They’re gay.


This might come as a turn-off to you.  I didn’t start this show to watch a gay relationship. But I wanted to see the skating, so I kept watching. And I ended up really liking their relationship, even more than I liked the skating. This show treats their romance like most other shows treat heterosexual romances: completely normally.  They don’t make it into a big deal. Yuri and Victor aren’t an obnoxious couple. Many tropes shown in other shounen-ai anime, like very explicit scenes and borderline abuse, are not present in Yuri on Ice. This show depicts the healthiest, most accurate depiction of a gay relationship I’ve ever seen in anime.  And by the end, I was cheering their relationship on 1000%.


Unfortunately, the show's conclusion was rushed, which was why I ended up rating Story an 8/10.


Art: 7/10


For the most part, the art is good. The characters are designed really well. My biggest issue with the art is that it is very inconsistent during the most important parts of the show: the skating competitions. One episode might show Yuri skating his short program with beautiful art. Another might show the same program with choppy, art that is clearly not as good. It didn’t hinder the show as a whole, but it would have been nice to see some consistent high quality art.



Sound: 10/10


The OP and ED are amazing.  This show relies heavily upon music, since the skaters compete with songs.  This is very well done. The lyrics are spot-on, and the music sounds great. I especially loved the music for Yuri’s short program and his free skate. They sum up the feeling of the show very well, and I never once got tired of hearing them. Yes. I downloaded them.  



Characters: 10/10


Yuri, the main character, is someone I could easily relate to. He has a clear goal, but he lacks self-confidence. When he failed, he felt like he let down everyone who supported him or cheered him on.  He’s the best skater in Japan, and he still feels inadequate. Despite his low self-esteem, Yuri isn’t whiny and annoying. He doesn’t blame others for his problems, and he works hard to achieve his goal.  He isn’t perfect. He’s believable, and that what makes a show like this good. His relationship with Victor really changes him for the better, which is really great to see.


Yuri’s rival, a younger Russian skater (who is coincidentally also named Yuri) is also a really interesting character. He’s practically the opposite of Yuri: brimming with confidence, conceited, and rude. Despite having much less screen time, his character develops almost as much as the other Yuri, and the differences between these two characters make their individual traits shine.


The side characters in this show are what make it so special. From the Canadian skater JJ, who is the most confident, (dare I say arrogant?) skater, who literally calls himself King JJ, to the adorable, hamster-loving Thai skater Pichit, who is a pure little cinnamon roll, this show makes its supporting cast shine.  There’s a skater who can’t get over his ex-girlfriend, a veteran skater who has competed alongside Victor for years, and a strong-and-silent type skater with a soft side. They aren’t cardboard cutouts. These characters all have realistic ambitions and mannerisms, and that makes them really fun to watch.  


Enjoyment: 10/10


This show absolutely exceeded my expectations. If, like Victor, this show’s goal was to surprise the audience, then it absolutely succeeded.

This show never fails to make me feel warm and fuzzy and happy. I wish that other people would look past the relationships, even though that's something that I absolutely love and think was well done without it being too in your face. The story is one that I think a lot of people can relate to, feeling like a failure and finding someone or something that pushes you to be your best. The art and the sound are incredibly captivating. The characters are relatable and rather down to earth for the world of ice skating and the stereotypes that are generally tied to theworld of competitive figure skating. This is definitely a show I would recommend to anyone who just wants to smile and feel good about the world. I'm not gonna lie, I was slightly offput when I first heard about it, but now it's in my top 5. Not to mention how amazing the opening and closing are. There isn't a day that I don't listen to the songs in this masterpiece. I'm anxiously waiting for a second season.

I really had high hopes for Yuri!!On ice when it was first released , since I love figure skating and wished they'd make an anime about it, (was more into ladies' figure skating), and I was disappointed after watching the 7th episode, I liked the first two episodes, but then the animation started getting..crappier? The scenes were changing so fast, there weren't those nice anime silent moments anymore, and they started turning it into a yaoi rather than focusing on the sport itself, I wished they spent more time creating good animation when it came to skating,and also on the characters, even though I likeVictor. In the end I'll just say that this anime doesn't make me anticipate the end, it seems rather predictable, Yuri will win for sure, I just don't see the struggles really.

First off, I just wanna say I voted 10 to try and counter a little bit all of the negative puntuations this show is getting just because it has gay characters in it.
That said, I will be honest with this review: YOI is a good anime. It is nice, enjoyable and interesting.
The music was just great. I liked the OP more than the ED, but both were pretty good. And the music used during performances were just perfect for each one of them. However, though you could understand what they were trying to express with each one, I think they failed to make their individualfeelings reach out, and they relied on other characters explaining how the skaters felt. It is also possible that I wasn't concentrated enough to realize though.\n\n
As for the characters and the story, I liked them a lot. I like how they explained characters, their backgrounds and motivations, but I also think that maybe they overdid it. I can't bring myself to love a character I've just been presented to if I'm getting another character presented to me almost at the same time the first one comes out of scene, which is usually like three minutes later.\n
On the other hand, it is still true that you see a bunch of them throughout the series and none of them feels like they shouldn't be there and all of them have a unique personality and (kinda) development. Also they're very well designed and non-exxagerated.\n

This Anime actually started quite well. The first episode had everything: Great animations, sympathical characters as it seemed and a neat story of fun an feeling. Unfortunately, from the beginning to the end, the overall quality tends to drop dramatically. 
Of course you can't expect as much passion in every episode as in the first one, however, holding up an average of quality should have been possible. In the middle of the anime everything is thrown into disarry.
The quality of animation declines rapidly, characters often appear in a very reduced way, like chibi-style. This may supposed to be fun and it certainly is at somepoint, but this rather gave me the impression that the staff wanted to save work instead. Sadly this becomes clear during the ice-skating scenes, which often appeared stiff to me, though most of the effort should have been put into these animations since ice-skating is the main topic of this sports-anime.


Alongside the animation, the story also suffers as time goes by due to vast amounts of new characters suddenly thrown into the anime. It is true that one tried to give those characters depth by using flashbacks to tell their backround storys, still I couldn't help feeling overwhelmed by the sheer amount of them and so unable to relate to their feelings. Several characters hardly have any screentime, though they seemed to be much more imprtant (like the best friend of the main character Yuri).

So I wonder: Was it really that difficult to put less characters into the anime in order to give the remaining ones more space to evolve? I mean even one of the main characters desperately needed some more screentime.

Naturally, a sports anime that includes a competiton needs many characters, but then one shouldn't have squashed them into mere twelve episodes. In any case all these ice-skaters make you loose the guiding thread, through I'm not sure if there is one to begin with.


Both the animation and story quality slightly increases towards the end of the anime, but it doesn't reach the touchstone of episode one, which is to be expected anyway. The last episode seemed pretty rushed so the anime left no good impression on me in the end.


The main tropic of this show, ice-skating, is quite unusual for an sports-anime. In fact I don't even know whether this topic ever came up before. It certainly isn't surprising that someone like me, who has absolutely no idea what ice-skating is all about, fails to understand what those ice-skaters are doing except carrying out one pirouette after another. So I can't really say if the sport itself is well presented in the anime.


The only thing of Yuri on ICE that striked positive to me was the music, which is outstanding in my opinion. Opening and ending songs are quite exceptional for an anime and also the piano piece during Yuri's ice-skating sessions is just beautiful, a true masterpiece.


If the overall quality of the anime would have been at least about half the music quality, this could have been a great anime. But due to the vast amount of characters entering the scene in the middle of the show, the anime clearly vastes its potential.
